content.question: Which of the following is true about the geometry of the glycinium cation?

choices.label: The leftmost <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> atom and all the atoms directly bonded to it lie in the same plane.

Both <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> atoms and both <math alttext="O" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> atoms lie in the same plane.

The <math alttext="N C C " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>N</mtext><mo>−</mo><mtext>C</mtext><mo>−</mo><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> bond angle is <math alttext="180 degrees" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>180</mn><mi>°</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.
The geometry around the <math alttext="N" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>N</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> atom is planar.

content.answer: Both <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> atoms and both <math alttext="O" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> atoms lie in the same plane.
